I'm going to add some facts about functions of the form f(t)=∑jajtkjeλjtf(t)=\sum_j a_jt^{k_j}e^{λ_jt}f(t)=∑j​aj​tkj​eλj​t. Two use cases I have in mind are

  • solutions of linear differential equations x˙(t)=Ax(t)+f(t)\dot x(t)=Ax(t)+f(t)x˙(t)=Ax(t)+f(t);
  • they naturally appear as partial sums of asymptotic series expansion of the correspondence map of a hyperbolic saddle point.

I have a few questions:

  1. How should I call them? I saw the name "quasi polynomials" in some sources (mostly in Russian) but wiki disagrees.

  2. How general should be the definition? I know about applications in these cases:

    • all aja_jaj​, λjλ_jλj​, and ttt are numbers (real or a complex);
    • aja_jaj​ is a matrix, λjλ_jλj​ and ttt are real or complex numbers;
    • aja_jaj​ and ttt are numbers, λjλ_jλj​ is a matrix (actually, it is λjAλ_jAλj​A).
Is this finite sums you're talking about?

Let me elaborate on applications.

If AAA is a matrix with eigenvalues λjλ_jλj​ with multiplicities rjr_jrj​, then x(t)=eAtx(0)x(t)=e^{At}x(0)x(t)=eAtx(0). Let Δ ⁣:(R+,0)→(R+,0)Δ\colon (\mathbb R_+, 0) → (\mathbb R_+, 0)Δ:(R+​,0)→(R+​,0) be the correspondence map of an analytic hyperbolic saddle and F(t)=−ln⁡Δ(e−t)F(t)=-\ln Δ(e^{-t})F(t)=−lnΔ(e−t), F ⁣:(R+,∞)→(R+,∞)F\colon (\mathbb R_+, \infty)\to(\mathbb R_+, \infty)F:(R+​,∞)→(R+​,∞), be the same map written in the logarithmic chart. Then for each Λ>0Λ>0Λ>0 we have

as t→∞t\to\inftyt→∞, where 0<λj≤Λ0<λ_j\le Λ0<λj​≤Λ and PjP_jPj​ are polynomials. The functions in the RHS can be glued into an asymptotic series

at+b+∑j=1∞Pj(t)e−λjt.at+b+\sum_{j=1}^∞ P_j(t)e^{-λ_jt}.at+b+j=1∑∞​Pj​(t)e−λj​t.

This series may diverge but it is an asymptotic series for FFF.

Moreover, the same asymptotic expansion holds true in the image ΩC\Omega_CΩC​ of the complex right half-plane under the map z↦z+C1+zz\mapsto z+C\sqrt{1+z}z↦z+C1+z​ for sufficiently large positive CCC. The latter fact together with a special version of the Phragmen-Lindelöf principle implies that the Poincaré map of a hyperbolic polycycle is either the identity map, or has an isolated fixed point at zero (Ilyashenko, about 1990).
Note I've made a bunch of progress on matrix exponentials specifically with (the first half of) that first example in mind
My main goal is the second application but IMHO we should have a definition that works in both cases.
